Historical epidemics and pandemics have challenged the surgical community to adapt and advance in unprecedented ways. These challenges have fostered development of modern surgical care and will continue to alter the trajectory of the field. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic is no exception. The American College of Surgeons (ACS) has published “COVID-19 and Surgery,” a comprehensive evidence-based resource to guide surgeons through challenges of the ongoing pandemic.
42 This organized response by a professional society has roots dating back to surgical guilds and efforts by surgeons to advance pragmatic solutions during the Black Death. “COVID-19 and Surgery” includes guidance on clinical care, PPE, ethical considerations, research, and legislation based on lessons from past infectious disease outbreaks.
42 For example, ethical frameworks for allocating scarce resources, such as ICU beds, ventilators, PPE, antiviral medications, and investigational vaccines draw from the same ethical principles of beneficence, justice, and respect for persons reinforced during the HIV/AIDS epidemic.
42 To allocate a limited supply of remdesivir, an antiviral medication being used to treat COVID-19, Pennsylvania endorsed a controversial weighted lottery that considers factors like socioeconomic status based on the ethical principle of justice.
43 Additionally, enhanced PPE recommendations were informed by lessons learned from the SARS and Ebola epidemics.
